title: COVID-19 and the 2019-2020 NHANES Cycle
text: 2019-2020 NHANES survey cycle (suffix K) included datasets provided package. vignette explains means analyses.

title: COVID-19 and the 2019-2020 NHANES Cycle
text: NHANES data collection operates continuous two-year cycle. 2019-2020 cycle began schedule suspended March 2020 due COVID-19 pandemic. partial data collected fieldwork stopped. CDC determined incomplete 2019-2020 data treated standard NHANES cycle. Instead, agency released separately “pre-pandemic” dataset combined components subsequent 2021-2023 cycle.

title: COVID-19 and the 2019-2020 NHANES Cycle
text: NHANES cycles use alphabetical suffixes: DEMO (1999-2000), DEMO_B (2001-2002), DEMO_C (2003-2004), DEMO_J (2017-2018). 2019-2020 cycle suffix K. cycle excluded, datasets skip suffix J directly suffix L (2021-2023): load dataset read_nhanes(), year column show values 1999 2017, jump 2021. year == 2019 dataset.

title: COVID-19 and the 2019-2020 NHANES Cycle
text: Incomplete data collection. CDC suspended fieldwork partway cycle, sample representative U.S. population way complete NHANES cycles . Non-standard release format. CDC published data different naming conventions file structures standard NHANES cycles, complicates automated processing. Analytical validity. CDC explicitly advises combining partial 2019-2020 data standard two-year cycles analyses.

title: COVID-19 and the 2019-2020 NHANES Cycle
text: full details 2019-2020 data release CDC’s guidance use, see: NHANES 2019-2020 Overview NCHS Data Brief pandemic’s impact NHANES

title: COVID-19 and the 2019-2020 NHANES Cycle
text: plan incorporate 2019-2020 pre-pandemic data future release. requires careful handling non-standard naming conventions clear documentation users understand limitations cycle. available, data clearly flagged inadvertently mixed standard cycles.

what: What to Do in the Meantime
title: COVID-19 and the 2019-2020 NHANES Cycle
text: analysis requires 2019-2020 data, can access pre-pandemic files directly CDC using nhanesA package: Note CDC uses P_ prefix (rather _K suffix) pre-pandemic tables. Consult CDC documentation linked correct table names.
code: library(nhanesA)  # Access 2019-2020 pre-pandemic demographics demo_k <- nhanesA::nhanes("P_DEMO")

title: Getting Started with NHANES Data
text: National Health Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES) one widely used public health datasets U.S., spanning two decades continuous data collection. Working NHANES data directly CDC presents two recurring problems: Server reliability. CDC’s data servers frequently slow unresponsive, breaks reproducible workflows. Cycle management. CDC publishes data two-year cycles letter suffixes (DEMO, DEMO_B, …, DEMO_L). Combining cycles requires tracking naming conventions reconciling type differences across waves. nhanesdata addresses issues hosting pre-merged, type-harmonized datasets Cloudflare R2 public access. single call read_nhanes("demo") returns demographics data 1999-2023 year column identifying survey cycle.

title: Getting Started with NHANES Data
text: package builds nhanesA package, provides underlying interface NHANES data R.

title: Getting Started with NHANES Data
code: # install.packages("pak") pak::pak("kyleGrealis/nhanesdata") library(nhanesdata) library(dplyr) library(ggplot2)

title: Getting Started with NHANES Data
text: Every dataset includes two key columns: year: Survey cycle start year (1999, 2001, 2003, …, 2017, 2021) seqn: Respondent sequence number (unique within cycle, used joining) Dataset names case-insensitive: "demo", "DEMO", "Demo" work.
code: #> Loading: DEMO #> DEMO complete! (113,249 rows) demo <- read_nhanes("demo") glimpse(demo)

title: Getting Started with NHANES Data
code: demo |>   filter(!is.na(ridageyr)) |>   ggplot(aes(x = ridageyr)) +   geom_histogram(binwidth = 5, fill = "steelblue", color = "white") +   facet_wrap(~year, ncol = 4) +   labs(     title = "NHANES Age Distribution by Survey Cycle",     x = "Age (years)",     y = "Count"   ) +   theme_minimal()

title: Getting Started with NHANES Data
text: call read_nhanes("demo"), receive data CDC publishes across multiple cycle-specific tables: matters need CDC documentation specific variable. Use get_url() retrieve codebook URL cycle-specific table: 2019-2020 cycle (suffix K) excluded datasets. See vignette("covid-data-exclusion") details.
code: get_url("DEMO")   # 1999-2000 codebook get_url("DEMO_I") # 2015-2016 codebook

title: Getting Started with NHANES Data
text: Combine datasets using seqn year join keys: Always join seqn year. seqn unique within cycle, joining columns ensures participants matched within survey period.
code: demo <- read_nhanes("demo") bpx <- read_nhanes("bpx") bmx <- read_nhanes("bmx")  analysis_data <- demo |>   inner_join(bpx, by = c("seqn", "year")) |>   inner_join(bmx, by = c("seqn", "year")) |>   select(year, seqn, ridageyr, riagendr, bpxsy1, bmxbmi)

title: Getting Started with NHANES Data
code: demo <- read_nhanes("demo")  # Recent cycles only recent <- demo |>   filter(year >= 2015)  # Compare time periods demo |>   mutate(     period = case_when(       year < 2010 ~ "1999-2009",       year < 2020 ~ "2010-2019",       TRUE ~ "2020+"     )   ) |>   group_by(period) |>   summarise(n = n())

title: Getting Started with NHANES Data
text: Returns variable names, table names, descriptions, collection years. can identify base table name (e.g., BPX) use read_nhanes().
code: term_search("blood pressure")

title: Getting Started with NHANES Data
text: Shows cycles contain specific variable.
code: var_search("BPXSY1")

title: Getting Started with NHANES Data
text: search functions case-insensitive.
code: #> Loading: BMX #> BMX complete! (96,288 rows) "bmxht" %in% names(bmx) #> [1] TRUE

what: Complete Example: Blood Pressure by Age Group
title: Getting Started with NHANES Data
code: demo <- read_nhanes("demo") bpx <- read_nhanes("bpx")  bp_analysis <- demo |>   filter(ridageyr >= 18) |>   select(seqn, year, ridageyr, riagendr, ridreth1) |>   inner_join(     bpx |> select(seqn, year, bpxsy1, bpxdi1),     by = c("seqn", "year")   ) |>   filter(!is.na(bpxsy1), !is.na(bpxdi1), bpxsy1 > 0, bpxdi1 > 0) |>   mutate(     age_group = cut(       ridageyr,       breaks = c(18, 30, 40, 50, 60, 70, 80, Inf),       labels = c(         "18-29", "30-39", "40-49", "50-59",         "60-69", "70-79", "80+"       ),       right = FALSE     )   )  bp_summary <- bp_analysis |>   group_by(age_group) |>   summarize(     n = n(),     mean_systolic = mean(bpxsy1),     mean_diastolic = mean(bpxdi1),     .groups = "drop"   ) bp_summary |>   ggplot(aes(x = age_group)) +   geom_col(aes(y = mean_systolic), fill = "coral", alpha = 0.7) +   geom_col(aes(y = mean_diastolic), fill = "steelblue", alpha = 0.7) +   labs(     title = "Blood Pressure Increases with Age",     subtitle = "Mean systolic (coral) and diastolic (blue) BP by age group",     x = "Age Group",     y = "Blood Pressure (mmHg)"   ) +   theme_minimal() +   theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1))

title: Getting Started with NHANES Data
text: Browse dataset catalog full list available tables Learn creating survey design objects proper weighting multi-cycle analyses Read 2019-2020 cycle exclusion Use ?read_nhanes function documentation File issues feature requests GitHub

title: Creating Survey Design Objects
text: NHANES uses complex, multistage probability sampling design select participants represent non-institutionalized U.S. population. Without proper survey weights, analyses produce biased estimates. create_design() function automates calculation appropriate weights combining multiple NHANES cycles, following CDC weighting guidelines.

title: Creating Survey Design Objects
text: NHANES provides three categories sampling weights, reflecting different levels participation: Interview weights (wtint2yr, wtint4yr): Used variables come household interview (demographics, questionnaires). Mobile Exam Center (MEC) weights (wtmec2yr, wtmec4yr): Used variable requires physical exam (laboratory tests, body measurements, DEXA scans). Fasting weights (wtsaf2yr): Used variable requires fasting laboratory tests (glucose, insulin, lipids). probability sampled decreases interview MEC fasting subsamples. combining variables across categories, always use weight lowest probability selection. example, analysis includes demographics (interview) body measurements (MEC), use MEC weights.

title: Creating Survey Design Objects
text: CDC recommendations combining cycles based number cycles present data, timespan covered. distinction matters gaps data.

title: Creating Survey Design Objects
text: NHANES provides 4-year weights (wtint4yr, wtmec4yr) 1999-2000 2001-2002 cycles, subsequent cycles provide 2-year weights. combining multiple cycles: Cycles 1999 2001: Use 4-year weight × (2/n) numerator 2 4-year weight represents two 2-year cycles. Cycles 2003+: Use 2-year weight × (1/n) Denominator n: Total number cycles analysis

title: Creating Survey Design Objects
text: Combining 4 cycles (1999, 2001, 2003, 2005) MEC weights: 1999 & 2001: wtmec4yr * 2/4 = wtmec4yr * 0.5 2003 & 2005: wtmec2yr * 1/4 = wtmec2yr * 0.25 excluded 2003 cycle, 3 cycles total, : 1999 & 2001: wtmec4yr * 2/3 2005: wtmec2yr * 1/3 key principle: n number cycles present, timespan.

title: Creating Survey Design Objects
code: library(nhanesdata) library(dplyr) library(srvyr)

title: Creating Survey Design Objects
text: analyzing demographics questionnaire data :
code: # Load demographics data demo <- read_nhanes("demo")  # Create design with interview weights design_int <- create_design(   dsn = demo,   start_yr = 1999,   end_yr = 2011,   wt_type = "interview" )  # Calculate weighted means design_int |>   summarize(     mean_age = survey_mean(ridageyr, na.rm = TRUE),     pct_female = survey_mean(riagendr == 2, na.rm = TRUE)   )

title: Creating Survey Design Objects
text: including examination laboratory data:
code: # Load demographics and body measures demo <- read_nhanes("demo") bmx <- read_nhanes("bmx")  combined <- demo |>   left_join(bmx, by = c("seqn", "year"))  # Use MEC weights because body measures require exam participation design_mec <- create_design(   dsn = combined,   start_yr = 2007,   end_yr = 2017,   wt_type = "mec" )  # Weighted BMI analysis design_mec |>   filter(!is.na(bmxbmi)) |>   summarize(     mean_bmi = survey_mean(bmxbmi, na.rm = TRUE),     pct_obese = survey_mean(bmxbmi >= 30, na.rm = TRUE)   )

title: Creating Survey Design Objects
text: including fasting laboratory measurements:
code: # Load demographics and fasting lab data demo <- read_nhanes("demo") glu <- read_nhanes("glu")  combined <- demo |>   left_join(glu, by = c("seqn", "year"))  # Use fasting weights for glucose analysis design_fast <- create_design(   dsn = combined,   start_yr = 2005,   end_yr = 2015,   wt_type = "fasting" )  # Analyze fasting glucose design_fast |>   filter(!is.na(lbxglu)) |>   summarize(     mean_glucose = survey_mean(lbxglu, na.rm = TRUE)   )

title: Creating Survey Design Objects
text: can specify wide year range even cycles missing data. function calculates weights based cycles actually present:
code: # Data might be missing 2007-2010 cycles # Weights calculated on cycles present, not timespan design <- create_design(   dsn = demo,   start_yr = 1999,   end_yr = 2017,   wt_type = "interview" )

title: Creating Survey Design Objects
text: creating survey design, participants may lack weight variable needed analysis. happens naturally NHANES everyone completes every component. create_design() handles : Participants without valid weights chosen weight type automatically filtered creating design object ’ll see message indicating many participants removed message includes links CDC guidance vignette reference Example message might see: Zero weights different missing weights: Participants zero weights retained design object participants weren’t selected particular subsample ’re automatically excluded analyses {survey} package correct behavior per CDC guidelines
code: Filtered out 150 participants without valid mec weights. These participants were not in the subsample for this weight category. Learn more:   + CDC weighting guidance:     https://wwwn.cdc.gov/nchs/nhanes/tutorials/Weighting.aspx   + Survey design vignette: vignette('survey-design', package = 'nhanesdata')

title: Creating Survey Design Objects
text: NHANES uses stratified, multistage sampling design Primary Sampling Units (PSUs) nested within strata. Variance estimation requires least 2 PSUs per stratum. subsetting data (e.g., filtering diabetes patients ), may create strata one PSU. create_design() function sets options(survey.lonely.psu = "adjust"), handles conservatively centering single-PSU strata sample grand mean rather stratum mean. approach: Prevents errors encountering lonely PSUs Provides conservative variance estimates Follows best practices subset analyses details lonely PSU handling, see Thomas Lumley’s {survey} package documentation.

title: Creating Survey Design Objects
text: function validates dataset contains: year: NHANES cycle start year (odd years: 1999, 2001, 2003, …, 2021) sdmvpsu: Primary sampling units sdmvstra: Sampling strata Interview: wtint2yr (wtint4yr 1999/2001 cycles present) MEC: wtmec2yr (wtmec4yr 1999/2001 cycles present) Fasting: wtsaf2yr variables automatically included datasets loaded via read_nhanes().

title: Creating Survey Design Objects
text: Load combine datasets using read_nhanes() {dplyr} joins Preprocess variables (recode, create derived variables, apply exclusions) Create design object create_design() Perform weighted analyses using {srvyr} {survey} functions Preprocessing design creation strongly recommended. design object created, filtering recoding become complex due survey structure.

title: Creating Survey Design Objects
text: CDC NHANES Tutorials: Official guidance survey weighting variance estimation CDC Weighting Module: Specific information combining survey cycles {survey} package documentation: Comprehensive guide complex survey analysis R {srvyr} package: Tidyverse-friendly wrapper {survey} package functions

what: nhanesdata: Pre-processed NHANES Data with Automated Updates
title: nhanesdata: Pre-processed NHANES Data with Automated Updates
text: National Health Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES) one comprehensive public health datasets available, spanning two decades U.S. health data. working frustrating. ’ve tried using NHANES , ’ve likely hit two major problems: (1) CDC server reliability issues break reproducible research, (2) cycle suffix confusion, finding DEMO, DEMO_B, DEMO_C, way DEMO_L makes data discovery scavenger hunt. nhanesdata solves problems. datasets hosted reliable cloud storage fast access, survey cycles already merged. Just use read_nhanes("demo") get demographics data 1999-2023 year column tracking cycle observation belongs . CDC server timeouts, suffix confusion. processed datasets publicly available https://nhanes.kylegrealis.com/ authentication required.

title: nhanesdata: Pre-processed NHANES Data with Automated Updates
text: package builds nhanesA package, provides foundation accessing NHANES data R.

title: nhanesdata: Pre-processed NHANES Data with Automated Updates
code: # From CRAN (submitted for approval Feb. 18, 2026) install.packages("nhanesdata")  # Development version from GitHub pak::pak("kyleGrealis/nhanesdata")

title: nhanesdata: Pre-processed NHANES Data with Automated Updates
text: datasets include year column (survey cycle start year) seqn (participant ID). Join datasets columns:
code: library(nhanesdata)  # Load any dataset (case-insensitive) demo   <- read_nhanes("demo")    # Demographics bpx    <- read_nhanes("BPX")     # Blood pressure trigly <- read_nhanes("TRIGLY")   # Triglycerides  # Search for variables term_search("diabetes") # By keyword var_search("RIDAGEYR")  # By variable name  # Get CDC documentation get_url("DEMO_J") library(dplyr)  analysis <- read_nhanes("demo") |>   inner_join(read_nhanes("bpx"), by = c("seqn", "year"))

title: nhanesdata: Pre-processed NHANES Data with Automated Updates
text: functions case-insensitive.

Always verify definitions get_url() since variable usage may differ across cycles. Data types automatically harmonized across cycles (integer vs. double, factor vs. character).

what: Calculate survey design weight within a NHANES dataset — create_design
title: Calculate survey design weight within a NHANES dataset — create_design
text: Input NHANES dataset apply proper weight calculation. 3 categories weights: Interview weight Mobile Exam Center (MEC) weight Fasting weight probability sampled type NHANES category decreases interview fasting samples. Therefore, selecting proper weight, practitioner use weight lowest probability combining variables across categories. example, performing analysis using demographics (interview), diabetes information (interview), DEXA scanning (MEC), associated MEC weight proper weight variable use. also important select proper year grouping cycle. NHANES cycles 1999 2001 use 4-year sample weights, subsequent cycles use 2-year sample weights. type combination requires careful attention : variables used, determine weight category (interview, MEC, fasting). cycles (years) used, select proper year grouping variable. function allow user input dataset, select analysis start & end years, specify type weight category. resulting survey design calculate proper weight apply creating design object. NOTE: required specify variables function highly recommended perform preprocessing variables creating complex design object. See also as_survey_design

title: Calculate survey design weight within a NHANES dataset — create_design
code: create_design(   dsn,   start_yr,   end_yr,   wt_type = c("interview", "mec", "fasting") )

title: Calculate survey design weight within a NHANES dataset — create_design
text: dsn Tibble data-frame. start_yr Numeric. Lower bound year filtering (inclusive). Must odd year representing valid NHANES cycle start: 1999, 2001, 2003, ..., 2019, 2021. example, use 2007 2007-2008 cycle. Data filtered include years start_yr end_yr. end_yr Numeric. Upper bound year filtering (inclusive). Must odd year >= start_yr. Weight calculations based number cycles actually present filtered data, valid gaps (e.g., start_yr=1999, end_yr=2017 2007-2010 missing). wt_type Character. Category weight used. Use weight category lowest probability selection, least one variable category used. Accepts full names ("interview", "mec", "fasting") abbreviations ("int", "mec", "fast").

title: Calculate survey design weight within a NHANES dataset — create_design
text: survey design object class tbl_svy (srvyr package) containing calculated design weights survey design metadata (PSUs, strata). Participants without valid weights specified weight type automatically filtered design object creation. Participants zero weights retained design object automatically excluded survey analyses.

title: Calculate survey design weight within a NHANES dataset — create_design
text: Weight Calculation Combined Cycles NHANES provides 4-year weights 1999-2000 2001-2002 cycles, subsequent cycles provide 2-year weights. combining multiple cycles: 1999 2001 cycles included: Use 4-year weight variable multiplied 2/n n total number cycles. numerator 2 4-year weight represents two 2-year cycles. cycles 2003 beyond: Use 2-year weight variable multiplied 1/n. denominator n always total number cycles analysis. Example: Combining 4 cycles (1999, 2001, 2003, 2005): 1999 & 2001: wtmec4yr * 2/4 2003 & 2005: wtmec2yr * 1/4 Fasting weights (wtsaf2yr) used 1/n multiplication. NOTE: 4-year fasting weights (wtsaf4yr) exist NHANES laboratory files 1999-2002 currently supported function. Fasting Subsample Weights fasting subsample analyses combining 1999-2002 cycles, 4-year fasting weight (WTSAF4YR) exists laboratory files (e.g., LAB10AM, LAB13AM) typically demographic files obtained via nhanesA. dataset includes merged laboratory fasting data 1999-2002, ensure WTSAF4YR present. Otherwise, function assumes 2-year fasting weights (WTSAF2YR) available.

title: Calculate survey design weight within a NHANES dataset — create_design
code: # \donttest{ # Load demographics data demo <- read_nhanes("demo") #> Loading: DEMO #> DEMO complete! (113,249 rows)  # Create design object with interview weights design <- create_design(   dsn = demo,   start_yr = 1999,   end_yr = 2011,   wt_type = "interview" )  # Combine with examination data and use MEC weights bmx <- read_nhanes("bmx") #> Loading: BMX #> BMX complete! (96,288 rows) combined <- demo |>   dplyr::left_join(bmx, by = c("seqn", "year"))  design_mec <- create_design(   dsn = combined,   start_yr = 2007,   end_yr = 2017,   wt_type = "mec" ) #>  #> Note: 2428 participants have zero mec weights and will be retained in the #> design object. #> These participants were not in the subsample for this weight category #> and will be automatically excluded from analyses by the {survey} package. # }

what: Get CDC Documentation URL for NHANES Table — get_url
title: Get CDC Documentation URL for NHANES Table — get_url
text: Constructs returns full CDC documentation URL given NHANES table. function handles table names without cycle suffixes (e.g., "DEMO_J" 2017-2018 "DEMO" 1999-2000) automatically maps suffix appropriate survey cycle year.

title: Get CDC Documentation URL for NHANES Table — get_url
code: get_url(table)

title: Get CDC Documentation URL for NHANES Table — get_url
text: table Character. table variable information needed. Can include cycle suffix (e.g., "DEMO_J") (e.g., "DEMO"). case-sensitive.

title: Get CDC Documentation URL for NHANES Table — get_url
text: Character string (invisibly). Full URL CDC data documentation, codebook, frequencies returned invisibly also printed console via message() interactive use.

title: Get CDC Documentation URL for NHANES Table — get_url
code: # These examples will run and display URLs get_url("DEMO_J") # Demographics 2017-2018 #> https://wwwn.cdc.gov/nchs/data/nhanes/public/2017/datafiles/DEMO_J.htm get_url("diq_j") # Case-insensitive: Diabetes 2017-2018 #> https://wwwn.cdc.gov/nchs/data/nhanes/public/2017/datafiles/DIQ_J.htm get_url("DIQ") # No suffix = 1999-2000 cycle #> https://wwwn.cdc.gov/nchs/data/nhanes/public/1999/datafiles/DIQ.htm  # Capture the URL for programmatic use url <- get_url("BMX_J") #> https://wwwn.cdc.gov/nchs/data/nhanes/public/2017/datafiles/BMX_J.htm

what: nhanesdata: Harmonized Access to NHANES Survey Data — nhanesdata-package
title: nhanesdata: Harmonized Access to NHANES Survey Data — nhanesdata-package
text: Instant access harmonized National Health Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES) data spanning 1999-2023. Retrieve pre-processed datasets reliable cloud storage automatic type reconciliation integrated search tools variables datasets. Simplifies NHANES data workflows handling cycle management maintaining data consistency across survey waves. Data sourced https://www.cdc.gov/nchs/nhanes/.

title: nhanesdata: Harmonized Access to NHANES Survey Data — nhanesdata-package
text: Maintainer: Kyle Grealis kylegrealis@proton.(ORCID) contributors: Amrit Baral abaral3@jhu.edu (ORCID) [contributor] Natalie Neugaard nataliegoulett@gmail.com (ORCID) [contributor] Raymond Balise balise@miami.edu (ORCID) [contributor] Johannes Thrul jthrul@jhu.edu (ORCID) [contributor] Janardan Devkota jdevkot1@jhu.edu (ORCID) [contributor]

what: Read NHANES Data from Cloud Storage — read_nhanes
title: Read NHANES Data from Cloud Storage — read_nhanes
text: Downloads pre-processed NHANES data files cloud storage. Data includes survey cycles (1999-2023) automatically merged harmonized, quarterly updates.

title: Read NHANES Data from Cloud Storage — read_nhanes
code: read_nhanes(dataset)

title: Read NHANES Data from Cloud Storage — read_nhanes
text: dataset Character. NHANES dataset base name (e.g., "trigly", "demo"). Case-insensitive - use 'demo', 'DEMO', 'Demo' interchangeably. Must single string (length 1). Leading/trailing whitespace automatically trimmed.

title: Read NHANES Data from Cloud Storage — read_nhanes
text: tibble containing requested NHANES dataset across available survey cycles. Always includes year seqn columns plus dataset-specific variables.

title: Read NHANES Data from Cloud Storage — read_nhanes
text: function downloads NHANES datasets cloud storage (hosted nhanes.kylegrealis.com). datasets combine multiple survey cycles automatic type harmonization. Data updated quarterly via automated workflows pull fresh data CDC servers. Dataset names case-insensitive throughout package. Use uppercase (matches CDC documentation) lowercase (easier type) - work identically. Error handling: function validates inputs provides informative error messages dataset fails load (e.g., network issues, non-existent datasets, misspelled names). Error messages include attempted URL suggestions troubleshooting.

title: Read NHANES Data from Cloud Storage — read_nhanes
code: # \donttest{ # All case variations work identically: trigly <- read_nhanes("trigly") # Lowercase #> Loading: TRIGLY #> TRIGLY complete! (27,039 rows) demo <- read_nhanes("DEMO") # Uppercase #> Loading: DEMO #> DEMO complete! (113,249 rows) acq <- read_nhanes("Acq") # Mixed case #> Loading: ACQ #> ACQ complete! (89,381 rows) # }

what: Search NHANES Variables by Term or Phrase — term_search
title: Search NHANES Variables by Term or Phrase — term_search
text: convenience wrapper around nhanesA::nhanesSearch returns simplified, concise output focused variable names, descriptions, survey years. Results sorted year (recent first) variable name.

title: Search NHANES Variables by Term or Phrase — term_search
code: term_search(var)

title: Search NHANES Variables by Term or Phrase — term_search
text: var Character. Search term phrase find variable names descriptions. Case-insensitive. Special regex characters automatically escaped literal matching.

title: Search NHANES Variables by Term or Phrase — term_search
text: data.frame 4 columns: Variable.Name: NHANES variable code Variable.Description: Description variable Data.File.Name: Name data file containing variable Begin.Year: Starting year survey cycle (numeric) Results sorted Begin.Year (descending) Variable.Name. Returns empty data.frame correct structure matches found.

title: Search NHANES Variables by Term or Phrase — term_search
code: # \donttest{ # Search for diabetes-related variables (showing first 5 results) term_search("diabetes") |> head(5) #>   Variable.Name #> 1        DID040 #> 2        DIQ010 #> 3        DIQ160 #> 4        DIQ180 #> 5        DID040 #>                                                                                                               Variable.Description #> 1 How old {was SP/were you} when a doctor or other health professional first told {you/him/her} that {you/he/she} had diabetes or  #> 2 The next questions are about specific medical conditions. {Other than during pregnancy, {have you/has SP}/{Have you/Has SP}} eve #> 3 {Have you/Has SP} ever been told by a doctor or other health professional that {you have/SP has} any of the following:  prediabe #> 4                                 {Have you/Has SP} had a blood test for high blood sugar or diabetes within the past three years? #> 5 How old {was SP/were you} when a doctor or other health professional first told {you/him/her} that {you/he/she} had diabetes or  #>   Data.File.Name Begin.Year #> 1          DIQ_L       2021 #> 2          DIQ_L       2021 #> 3          DIQ_L       2021 #> 4          DIQ_L       2021 #> 5          DIQ_J       2017  # Search for blood pressure measurements (showing first 5 results) term_search("blood pressure") |> head(5) #>   Variable.Name #> 1        BPQ020 #> 2        BPQ030 #> 3        BPQ150 #> 4      BPAOMNTS #> 5        BPD035 #>                                                                                                               Variable.Description #> 1 {Have you/Has SP} ever been told by a doctor or other health professional that {you/s/he} had hypertension, also called high blo #> 2          {Were you/Was SP} told on 2 or more different visits that {you/s/he} had hypertension, also called high blood pressure? #> 3                    {Are you/Is SP} now taking any medication prescribed by a doctor for {your/his/her/SP's} high blood pressure? #> 4 Difference in minutes between blood pressure obtained by a physician with a mercury sphygmomanometer (legacy) and blood pressure #> 5       How old {were you/was SP} when {you were/he/she was} first told that {you/he/she} had hypertension or high blood pressure? #>   Data.File.Name Begin.Year #> 1          BPQ_L       2021 #> 2          BPQ_L       2021 #> 3          BPQ_L       2021 #> 4         BPXO_J       2017 #> 5          BPQ_J       2017 # }

title: Internal Utility Functions — utils
text: file contains internal helper functions used across nhanesdata package. functions exported meant internal package use .

what: Search for NHANES Variable by Exact Name — var_search
title: Search for NHANES Variable by Exact Name — var_search
text: convenience wrapper around nhanesA::nhanesSearchVarName searches variables exact variable name match. function automatically converts input uppercase match NHANES naming conventions. Use know variable code; use term_search() text-based searches.

title: Search for NHANES Variable by Exact Name — var_search
code: var_search(var)

title: Search for NHANES Variable by Exact Name — var_search
text: var Character. Variable name search . automatically converted uppercase. case-sensitive.

title: Search for NHANES Variable by Exact Name — var_search
text: character vector CDC table names containing variable (e.g., "DEMO", "DEMO_B", "DEMO_C"). Returns character(0) variable found.

title: Search for NHANES Variable by Exact Name — var_search
code: # \donttest{ # Search for specific variable (case-insensitive) var_search("RIDAGEYR") # Age variable across all DEMO cycles #>  [1] "DEMO"   "DEMO_B" "DEMO_C" "DEMO_D" "DEMO_E" "DEMO_F" "DEMO_G" "DEMO_H" #>  [9] "DEMO_I" "DEMO_J" "DEMO_L" "P_DEMO" var_search("BPXSY1") # Systolic blood pressure #>  [1] "BPX"   "BPX_B" "BPX_C" "BPX_D" "BPX_E" "BPX_F" "BPX_G" "BPX_H" "BPX_I" #> [10] "BPX_J" # }

title: nhanesdata 0.2.1
text: Converted vignettes Quarto (.qmd) R Markdown (.Rmd) fix vignette build failures Windows CI.

title: nhanesdata 0.2.1
text: Adding create_design() function return survey-weighted design data use downstream analyses. Combines cycles properly accounts weight type (interview, MEC, fasting) adheres CDC guidelines use earlier cycles. See CDC Weighting Guidelines information.

title: nhanesdata 0.2.0
text: Released: Feb. 2026

title: nhanesdata 0.2.0
text: Categorical columns across datasets now stored character human-readable labels instead raw numeric codes. example, BMX bmdbmic values like 2, 3, 4, 1 now "Normal weight", "Overweight", "Obese", "Underweight". affects 95 variables across 22 datasets.

title: nhanesdata 0.2.0
text: Fixed data corruption factor--numeric conversion returned internal level indices instead actual CDC codes (e.g., codes 1, 3, 4 silently stored 1, 2, 3). Fixed continuous variables like ridageyr indfmpir corrupted categorical label mappings incorrectly applied . Fixed column type clashes binding survey cycles column existed cycles others.

title: nhanesdata 0.2.0
text: Cross-cycle label translation: CDC codebook unavailable particular cycle, labels now carried sibling cycle waves consistent human-readable values. Added 5 new datasets: dxxag, l10, l10am, lab10, lab10am (71 datasets total). Added inst/CITATION citation("nhanesdata") support.

title: nhanesdata 0.2.0
text: Added Amrit Baral, Natalie Neugaard, Johannes Thrul, Janardan Devkota contributors.

title: nhanesdata 0.1.1
text: Released: Jan. 2026

title: nhanesdata 0.1.1
text: Automated quarterly data updates via GitHub Actions checksum-based change detection Cloudflare R2 uploads. Replaced pins direct R2 uploads simpler URL structure. Added dataset catalog vignette searchable table.

title: nhanesdata 0.1.0
text: read_r2() renamed read_nhanes(). pull_nhanes() longer exported; use read_nhanes() load data.

title: nhanesdata 0.1.0
text: Reduced required dependencies (moved 7 packages Suggests). Dataset names now case-insensitive. Improved error messages get_url() reliability.

title: nhanesdata 0.1.0
text: Fixed pull_nhanes() save() failed “object found” error. Fixed NULL handling term_search() var_search(). Fixed Begin.Year column converting numeric.

title: nhanesdata 0.0.0.9000 (2025-11-17)
text: Initial development version core functionality accessing managing NHANES data.
